text: Not all AIs are language models or art thieves.  AI has helped map proteins.  AI has helped the (astronomical) workload in astronomy.  It‚Äôs doing some things that humans can do, but it‚Äôs also doing things humans can‚Äôt do, because they‚Äôre too tedious.  Science communicators might care about that.

Thank you! I've been disaffected with LLMs for a long time, largely due to working in another area of AI research (specialized models for biomolecular predictions, like protein folding) that has found itself choked of funding by the LLM hype.

I don't think anyone was "pushed" towards generative AI: the progress in the past years has been akin to science fiction. I in particular work on generative models for life science that will make drug discovery faster and cheaper. Not sure how this is "capitalism not paying people"--we do pay well.

I've seen a thread about generating images of protein structures but I think it's more about machine learning  than LLMs

Machine learning can, in fact, be very useful for analyzing huge datasets, from folding proteins to traffic management.  GenAI in the form of large language models like ChatGPT can write you a terrible white paper about traffic management with bad ideas and hallucinated references.

This is a motte-and-bailey fallacy based on the colloquial usage of the word "AI" to refer to both machine learning models in general, and generative models such as ChatGPT. The latter is what everyone else here is talking about. To my knowledge, no LLM has ever folded a protein in its life.

Take a look at how AI is advancing things in science too; I expect that it'll help take care of those problems.  Physics and medical imaging come to mind, and the AlphaFold series that helped with protein-folding.   It's refreshing to find someone with a reasoned and sensible approach to this.

I chose protein folding specifically, it's an LLM using gen/AI.  Interestingly enough, you'd think radiology is ML alone, right? Well, no, it turns out that if you have a crappy image, gen/AI is how you make it better.
